questions.text: Which of the following is not included as a major component of Jones criteria for diagnosing acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Increased PR interval

questions.text: Choose the cardiac event that corresponds to the phase of isovolumetric contraction:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) c wave of JVP 

 

The c wave is seen in the jugular venous pulse due to bulging of the tricuspid valve during early ventricular contraction, which coincides with isovolumetric contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S3 heart sound: S3 occurs during early diastole, during the rapid ventricular filling phase, and is not associated with isovolumetric contraction.

 

Option B. S2 heart sound: S2 marks the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves at the end of systole, not during isovolumetric contraction.

 

Option C. QRS wave of ECG: The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization, which triggers isovolumetric contraction of the ventricles.

 

Mnemonic: Pa4 QRS 1Cx T2 dn v3y

choices.text: Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve

questions.text: A 46-year-old man complains of dyspnoea and chest discomfort. He believes that the symptoms are due to a respiratory infection he had 4 weeks ago, but he did not see a doctor at that time. ECHO is shown below. Which of the following additional findings may be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High-pitched, early diastolic sound

 

This describes a pericardial knock, which is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis—a known complication following viral infection affecting the heart. The echo shown likely demonstrates features of constrictive pericarditis, such as septal bounce and abnormal ventricular filling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve: This is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not typically following viral myocarditis or pericarditis; echo would show thickened septum and MV displacement, not constriction.

 

 

Option C. Delta wave on ECG: Indicates Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome due to an accessory pathway; aka canal of Kent. Image shows Delta wave and prolonged PR.

 

 

Option D. Inferonasal ectopia lentis: This is an ocular sign most commonly seen in homocystinuria, not in cardiac or pericardial conditions resulting from viral infection.

choices.text: Pruritus and flushing of the skin

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with hyperlipidemia comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His home medications include acetaminophen and atorvastatin. Serum studies show elevated total cholesterol and triglyceride concentrations. A drug that activates the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha is added to his existing therapy. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following drug-related adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reddish-brown discoloration of urine

 

This occurs due to myopathy or rhabdomyolysis, a known serious adverse effect of fibrates (PPAR-alpha activators) especially when combined with statins like atorvastatin. The muscle breakdown releases myoglobin, which colors the urine reddish-brown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waxing and waning confusion: This is not associated with fibrates; it suggests neurological causes unrelated to this drug class.

 

Option C. Pruritus and flushing of the skin: These are typical side effects of niacin, not fibrates.

 

Option D. Acutely swollen and painful joint: While fibrates can elevate uric acid levels increasing gout risk, this is less common than rhabdomyolysis and urine discoloration.

choices.text: Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node
Degeneration of the atrioventricular conduction system

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness while playing video games. He states this has occurred intermittently over the past year, but the episodes typically resolve spontaneously after a few minutes. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. ECG is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ectopic atrial pacemaker activity

 

Given the clinical presentation of a 17-year-old with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness, with intermittent episodes resolving spontaneously, this suggests a supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) of atrial origin.

 

The ECG likely shows a narrow complex tachycardia consistent with an atrial tachycardia arising from an ectopic atrial pacemaker.

 

Ectopic atrial pacemaker activity matches ectopic atrial tachycardia, causing palpitations from abnormal atrial impulses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node: Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node is typical of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, causing atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT), usually diagnosed with characteristic delta waves on ECG.

 

Option B. Degeneration of the atrioventricular conduction system: Degeneration of the AV conduction system causes heart block, uncommon in young patients and unlikely to cause SVT.

 

Option D. Dysfunction of the sinoatrial node: Dysfunction of the sinoatrial node results in bradycardia or pauses, not tachycardia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to severe right leg pain. Right-sided dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are absent, and the popliteal pulse is barely palpable. Emergency embolectomy is performed and a gelatinous mass causing arterial occlusion is successfully removed. Histopathologic section of the mass is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely origin of this patient's embolus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left atrium 

 

The image shows a myxoma, a benign gelatinous tumor frequent in the left atrium. Such a mass can embolize to peripheral arteries after detachment, causing acute arterial occlusion as described. Myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumors and are classically found in the left atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vein: Emboli from the venous system (e.g., femoral vein) typically cause pulmonary embolism, not arterial occlusion in the leg.

 

Option B. Descending aorta: Atheroemboli from the aorta could cause arterial occlusion, but histology would show cholesterol clefts, not myxoid material.

 

Option D. Left ventricle: Emboli from the left ventricle are usually due to mural thrombi, seen after myocardial infarction, not gelatinous myxoma tissue.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about beta blockers:

  1. Carvedilol is the most widely used beta blocker.
  2. These are drug of choice in acute decompensated heart failure.
  3. Pindolol would be less likely to induce severe bradycardia in comparison to the other β-blockers.
  4. Sotalol can prolong the AP duration leading to torsade’s de pointes.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

1. Carvedilol is the most widely used beta blocker: True. Carvedilol is a non-selective beta-blocker with alpha-blocking properties, widely used especially in heart failure management.

 

3. Pindolol would be less likely to induce severe bradycardia: True. Pindolol has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA), so it causes less bradycardia compared to other beta blockers.

 

4. Sotalol can prolong AP duration leading to torsade’s de pointes: True. Sotalol is a beta blocker with class III antiarrhythmic effects that prolong the action potential duration and QT interval, increasing risk of torsade de pointes.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

2. These are drug of choice in acute decompensated heart failure: False. Beta blockers are generally not initiated or used in acute decompensated heart failure due to risk of worsening cardiac function; they are preferred in chronic stable heart failure.

questions.text: 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department with light-headedness and generalized weakness for the last 2 days. He has chronic stable angina with exertion. However, over the last 2 days he has also had occasional chest discomfort at rest. The patient's medical problems include hypertension and bronchial asthma. He has no shortness of breath, cough, or peripheral edema. His only medications are aspirin and isosorbide dinitrate. Blood pressure is 105/66 mmHg. Electrocardiogram obtained in the emergency department is shown here. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac pacing

 

The ECG shows complete heart block (third-degree AV block) with regular P waves and independent, slow, wide QRS complexes. In a symptomatic patient—especially with light-headedness, weakness, and low blood pressure—this is an indication for urgent cardiac pacing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenosine: Used for supraventricular tachycardias, not for bradyarrhythmias or heart block; would worsen conduction block here.

 

Option C. Digoxin: Can exacerbate AV block by further slowing conduction—contraindicated in complete heart block.

 

Option D. Fibrinolytic therapy: Indicated for acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction, not for bradyarrhythmias without evidence of infarction on ECG.

questions.text: 64-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office due to generalized malaise and palpitations for the past 2 weeks. An echocardiogram last year showed mild left atrial dilation and left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient's medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Blood pressure is 170/90 mmHg. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diltiazem

 

  • The ECG shows atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm, no distinct P waves, variable R-R intervals). The patient is stable (no hypotension or acute heart failure symptoms), so the immediate goal is rate control. Diltiazem, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is effective and safe for rate control in atrial fibrillation in hemodynamically stable patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenosine: Used for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia; not effective for atrial fibrillation.

 

Option B. Electric cardioversion: Indicated if the patient is unstable (hypotension, shock, severe heart failure, or ischemia), which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Lidocaine: Used for ventricular arrhythmias, not atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: 35-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a routine physical examination. The patient reports occasional palpitations but has no other chronic medical problems. She has caries of right upper molar tooth and is due to have an extraction next week. She has no significant medical history but had been told that she has "a murmur." The patient's only medication is a daily oral contraceptive. She lives a sedentary lifestyle and reports no dyspnea on routine activity. She developed hives with use of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole in the past. Blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg and pulse is 70/min. Physical examination shows no jugular venous distension in the upright position. Normal vesicular breath sounds are heard on chest auscultation. A late systolic murmur heard over the apex prolongs with the Valsalva manoeuvre. Which of the following is recommended for this patient prior to the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No antibiotics

 

  • The murmur described (late systolic murmur at the apex that prolongs with Valsalva) suggests mitral valve prolapse (MVP).
  • Current guidelines do not recommend antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis in patients with MVP, even if they have a murmur.
  • The patient has no history of prosthetic heart valves, prior endocarditis, or certain high-risk cardiac conditions that would warrant prophylaxis.
  • She also has a penicillin allergy (hives with TMP-SMX suggests caution with antibiotics, though it's not penicillin), but antibiotic prophylaxis is not needed here regardless.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Intravenous ampicillin and Option B. Intravenous cefazolin are used in patients requiring prophylaxis but not indicated here.

 

Option D. Oral amoxicillin: Oral amoxicillin is the usual oral antibiotic for prophylaxis if indicated, but again, this patient does not meet criteria for prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office due to exertional dyspnea. The patient has a history of lgA nephropathy; she received hemodialysis for 2 years before undergoing kidney transplantation last month. Chest x-ray reveals cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion. Further evaluation determines that her symptoms are likely due to persistence of the arteriovenous fistula that was used for hemodialysis. Which of the following physiologic changes in 1) cardiac output, 2) systemic vascular resistance and 3) venous return respectively are present in this patient due to the fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increases, decreases, increases

 

  • Cardiac output increases because an arteriovenous (AV) fistula creates a low-resistance pathway, causing more blood to flow from arteries to veins directly. This increases venous return to the heart, which in turn increases cardiac output by the Frank-Starling mechanism.
  • Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) decreases due to the low resistance pathway created by the fistula; blood bypasses the high-resistance arteriolar bed and returns quickly to the venous system, lowering overall SVR.
  • Venous return increases because the fistula allows blood to flow directly into the venous system, increasing preload and venous return.

 

Thus, the AV fistula leads to increased cardiac output and venous return but decreased systemic vascular resistance

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure.
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure.
The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure.
Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.text: The true statement among the following is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

 

Besides being an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), losartan also has properties as a thromboxane A2 receptor antagonist, which inhibits platelet aggregation, contributing to its cardiovascular protective effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure: Usually telmisartan dose should be adjusted in hepatic failure since it is extensively metabolized in the liver; renal dose adjustment is less critical.

 

Option B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure: Generally, no dose adjustment is needed in mild to moderate hepatic or renal failure, but caution is advised in severe cases; dose reduction is not routinely required in mild-moderate failure.

 

Option C. The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure: Dose adjustment is usually required in renal impairment; hepatic metabolism is significant but dose reduction is mainly for renal failure, so the statement is incorrect.

questions.text: The cardiac output and venous return curves of a healthy person are shown below with solid lines. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the change depicted by the dashed lines?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myocardial infarction

 

The dashed lines in the graph show a reduced cardiac output curve (lower plateau) while the venous return curve remains unchanged. This pattern occurs when the heart's pumping efficiency is impaired, but blood volume and venous return capacity are not directly affected. In myocardial infarction, decreased contractility leads to reduced cardiac output, while venous return is initially preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive hydration: Would increase blood volume, shifting the venous return curve upward and to the right, but not primarily reduce cardiac output.

 

Option B. Acute hemorrhage: Would shift the venous return curve downward due to reduced circulating volume, but may not primarily depress the cardiac output plateau unless severe shock occurs.

 

Option C. Chronic anemia: Increases cardiac output due to compensatory mechanisms; it does not depress cardiac function at rest.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 3-day history of increasing chest tightness and intermittent sharp chest pains. The patient has no prior chronic medical conditions but had an upper respiratory illness a week ago that resolved without treatment. ECG reveals sinus tachycardia and low voltage QRS complexes that vary in the amplitude from beat to beat. Which of the following is the most likely chest x-ray finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 

 

 

The clinical scenario mentioned here is suggestive of CARDIAC TAMPONADE, shown in image B

 

The patient's presentation of chest tightness and sharp chest pain following an upper respiratory illness, combined with ECG findings of sinus tachycardia and low voltage QRS complexes with beat-to-beat variation in amplitude (electrical alternans), strongly suggests pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade.

 

  • The history of recent upper respiratory illness points to viral pericarditis leading to pericardial effusion.
  • Low voltage QRS complexes reflect fluid insulating the heart.
  • Electrical alternans (variation in QRS amplitude) is classic for large pericardial effusion with the heart swinging inside the fluid.
  • Sinus tachycardia is a compensatory response to reduced cardiac output.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Image A suggests TETROLOGY OF FALLOT, seen in infants.

 

Option C. Image C suggests PERICARDITIS, denoted by inflammatory thickening shown with white ARROW

 

Option D. Image D suggests TAPVC of supracardiac variety{FIGURE OF 8 sign} seen in infancy

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the OPD due to several weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema. Echocardiography shows biventricular dilation and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. After initial stabilization, long-term use of which of the following medications will most likely improve survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carvedilol

 

Carvedilol is a beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking properties, shown to improve survival, reduce hospitalization, and improve symptoms in patients with chronic systolic heart failure (low ejection fraction) by decreasing sympathetic nervous system overactivity[guidelines].

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Used to relieve symptoms of fluid overload but does not improve survival.

 

Option B. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker that does not improve survival in systolic heart failure and may worsen outcomes.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Improves symptoms and reduces hospitalizations but does not improve survival.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of mitral stenosis comes to the OPD. Cardiac auscultation reveals an opening snap and a rumbling murmur heard best in the left fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Timing of these sounds  best corresponds to which of the following letters?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

The opening snap in mitral stenosis occurs shortly after the mitral valve opens, which happens at the beginning of diastole, just as left ventricular pressure falls below left atrial pressure. On the pressure tracing, this corresponds to point C, where the left atrial pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure and the mitral valve opens, producing the opening snap heard on auscultation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A, B, D, E: These points do not match the precise moment after mitral valve opening; they relate to other phases (A: early systole,
  •  B: aortic valve opening,
  •  D: aortic closure, 
  •  E: just after systole).

 

Thus, timing of the opening snap best corresponds to C on the pressure tracing.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG is shown below. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Epinephrine

questions.text:
44-year-old man reports exertional shortness of breath and palpitations. On examination, he has a systolic murmur at the left sternal border and cardiac apex, which gets louder when he stands up. He is diagnosed with obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and is started on a medication. Changes in the action potential of ventricular muscle cells before and after administration of medication are shown in the image below. The patient is most likely being treated with which of the following medications?

 

 

The patient is most likely being treated with which of the following medications?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Disopyramide

questions.text: Deep y descent in JVP is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac tamponade

 

Deep y descent in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle. It is classically seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM), constrictive pericarditis, and tricuspid regurgitation due to unhindered or rapid filling phases.

 

  • In cardiac tamponade, the y descent is blunted or absent because the pericardial pressure impairs early diastolic filling and equalizes diastolic pressures, leading to a slow y descent.

 

Thus, deep y descent is absent in cardiac tamponade but present in the other coditions.

questions.text:
Arrange the following phases of cardiac cycle in sequential order from systole to diastole:

 

1. S1

2. S4

3. y descent

4. R wave
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4-1-3-2

 

Events given:

 

  1. S1 – first heart sound → due to closure of AV valves at the start of systole.
  2. S4 – atrial contraction sound (“atrial kick”) → occurs in late diastole, just before S1.
  3. y descent – fall in atrial pressure due to opening of AV valves and ventricular filling → early diastole.
  4. R wave – ECG ventricular depolarization → precedes ventricular systole, occurs just before S1.

 

Correct Sequence:

 

  • R wave (4) → ventricular depolarization → onset of systole.
  • S1 (1) → closure of AV valves → marks start of ventricular systole.
  • y descent (3) → rapid ventricular filling → early diastole.
  • S4 (2) → atrial contraction at end of diastole (presystolic).

 

So, sequence = 4 → 1 → 3 → 2

 

MNEMONIC : Pa4 QRS 1Cx T2dn v3y

questions.text: A 34-year-old man develops severe chest and abdominal pain while shopping in a mall. Paramedics arrive and find him in severe distress. Several minutes later, he suffers a cardiac arrest with pulseless electrical activity and cannot be resuscitated. Postmortem examination reveals an internal hemorrhage as the cause of death. Histochemical evaluation of the patient's tissues reveals a defect affecting a large extracellular glycoprotein. This protein is normally found abundantly in large blood vessels, periosteum, and zonular fibers of the lens and functions to form microfibrils by surrounding elastin. This patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Marfan syndrome

 

  • The defect described is in a large extracellular glycoprotein that forms microfibrils surrounding elastin, which is fibrillin-1. Fibrillin-1 is a major component of microfibrils in connective tissue and is abundant in large blood vessels, periosteum, and zonular fibers of the lens.
  • Mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene leads to Marfan syndrome, characterized by skeletal abnormalities, lens dislocation, and aortic root aneurysm prone to dissection and fatal hemorrhage.
  • The patient's sudden death due to internal hemorrhage from a blood vessel rupture fits the classic presentation of aortic dissection in Marfan syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome: Due to collagen defects, not fibrillin, and presents with skin hyperextensibility and joint hypermobility.

 

Option B. Homocystinuria: Also causes lens dislocation but classically inferiorly; presents with Marfanoid habitus but has elevated homocysteine.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Affects type I collagen causing brittle bones but no vascular microfibril defect.

questions.text: The absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis would indicate all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild mitral stenosis

 

  • The loud S1 in mitral stenosis is due to the forceful closure of a still mobile, but stenotic mitral valve.
  • Usually retains a normal or loud S1 because the valve is not yet heavily affected or immobile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcified valve: If the valve is heavily calcified and immobile, S1 is often diminished or absent because the valve closes less forcefully.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Can cause premature mitral valve closure, blunting the loudness of S1.

 

Option C. First degree heart block: Delays atrioventricular conduction, causing the mitral valve to close with less force, reducing S1 intensity. Therefore, absence of loud S1 would not be expected in mild mitral stenosis.

choices.text: The earth to all leads is in the right leg
Lead I: Positive pole to the right and negative pole towards the left
Lead II: Positive pole on the left arm and negative pole towards the right leg
Lead II: Positive pole on the right and negative pole towards the left

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the placement of ECG leads?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The earth to all leads is in the right leg

 

The earth (neutral) electrode is commonly placed on the right leg to serve as a reference point and reduce electrical interference in ECG recordings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lead I: The positive pole is on the left arm and the negative pole on the right arm, not the other way around.

 

Option C. Lead II: The positive pole is on the left leg and negative pole on the right arm.

 

Option D. Lead II: The positive pole is not on the right; it is on the left leg.

choices.text: Calcium current within the atrioventricular node
Calcium current within the sinoatrial node
Sodium current within an atrioventricular accessory pathway

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to palpitations and shortness of breath that began an hour ago. Medical history includes hypertension, coronary artery disease, and paroxysmal atrial flutter. Blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg and pulse is rapid. ECG shows atrial flutter with a ventricular rate of approximately 150/ min. The estimated atrial rate based on ECG flutter waves is 300/min. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the rate difference between the atria and the ventricles?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium current within the atrioventricular node

 

  • The atrioventricular (AV) node controls conduction of electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles and protects the ventricles from excessively rapid rates during atrial arrhythmias like atrial flutter or fibrillation.
  • The AV node relies primarily on slow calcium currents (L-type calcium channels) for depolarization, which limits the conduction rate and causes a ventricular rate slower than the atrial rate (e.g., 2:1 block with atrial flutter rate 300/min and ventricular rate ~150/min).
  • This property accounts for the difference between atrial and ventricular rates seen on ECG.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium current within the sinoatrial node: The SA node initiates normal 

heart rhythm but does not regulate ventricular rate in arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Sodium current within an AV accessory pathway: Accessory pathways conduct impulses via fast sodium channels but are involved in pre-excitation syndromes, not typical atrial flutter block.

 

Option D. Sodium current within the atria: Atrial depolarization depends on sodium current, but this does not determine ventricular rate blocking.

choices.text: Pericardial inflammation due to autoimmune reaction to necrotic tissue
Pericardial inflammation due to concomitant viral infection
Pericardial inflammation overlying the necrotic segment of myocardium
Recurrent thrombosis of the culprit coronary vessel

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with an acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. The patient undergoes coronary angiography with stent placement in the left circumflex artery, and he is started on therapy with a beta blocker and antiplatelet agents. On day 3 of hospitalization he experiences chest pain. The pain, described as sharp and radiating to his neck and shoulders, is exacerbated by coughing and swallowing. Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 °F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min and regular, and respirations are 20/min. The lungs are clear on auscultation. There is no peripheral edema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's chest pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pericardial inflammation overlying the necrotic segment of myocardium

 

  • The patient developed sharp, pleuritic chest pain within days after an acute myocardial infarction (MI). This is typical of early (acute) pericarditis resulting from inflammation of the pericardium adjacent to the necrotic myocardium.
  • It usually occurs within the first few days (1-4 days) after MI and is characterized by chest pain worsened by coughing, swallowing, or deep breaths.
  • Fever and clear lung auscultation also support pericarditis rather than heart failure or recurrent ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericardial inflammation due to autoimmune reaction to necrotic tissue: Autoimmune reaction (Dressler syndrome): Occurs weeks to months post-MI, a delayed immune-mediated pericarditis.

 

Option B. Pericardial inflammation due to concomitant viral infection: Viral infection: Less likely in the immediate post-MI setting without other signs.

 

Option D. Recurrent thrombosis of the culprit coronary vessel: Would cause typical angina pain, not sharp pleuritic pain and would likely worsen hemodynamics.

questions.text: Identify the conduction abnormality from the ECG given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mobitz type 1

 

  • The ECG shows gradually increasing PR intervals until a beat is dropped (a P wave not followed by a QRS complex), and then the cycle repeats. This classic pattern is characteristic of Mobitz type 1 (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block.

  • Thus, the conduction abnormality is Mobitz type 1[Wencheback].

     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Consistently prolonged PR interval with no dropped beats.

 

Option C. Third degree heart block: Complete dissociation of P waves and QRS complexes, with no relation between them.

 

Option D. Mobitz type 2: Sudden dropped QRS complexes without preceding gradual PR prolongation.

choices.text: Decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic volume

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the OPD due to recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain. The episodes occur during physical activity, usually when he climbs stairs or walks uphill, and resolve after he rests for a few minutes. He is prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin to take as needed when the chest pain occurs. This drug is most likely to relieve this patient's symptoms by causing which of the following hemodynamic changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic volume 

 

  • Sublingual nitroglycerin primarily acts as a venodilator, which decreases preload by reducing venous return to the heart. This decreases left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV), thereby reducing myocardial wall stress and oxygen demand, which relieves angina symptoms.
  • Thus, nitroglycerin relieves symptoms mainly by decreasing LVEDV and myocardial oxygen consumption.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in heart rate: Nitroglycerin may reflexively increase heart rate due to vasodilation.

 

Option C. Decrease in peripheral arteriolar resistance: This is more characteristic of hydralazine; nitroglycerin causes minimal arteriolar dilation at therapeutic doses.

 

Option D. Increase in coronary blood flow: While nitroglycerin dilates epicardial coronary arteries, its main benefit in stable angina is reduction of myocardial oxygen demand through preload reduction.

questions.text: 34-year-old woman comes to the physician due to weakness, exertional dyspnea, and orthopnea. On cardiac auscultation, a snap followed by a rumbling diastolic murmur is heard over the cardiac apex. The snap most likely occurs nearest to which of the following points on the cardiac pressure-volume loop?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

  • The patient has classic signs of mitral stenosis: a snap (opening snap) followed by a rumbling diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex.
  • The opening snap occurs just after the mitral valve opens, which corresponds to the point where left ventricular pressure falls below left atrial pressure—this is point D on the pressure-volume loop, marking the start of diastolic filling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral valve closure (beginning of systole)

 

Option B. Aortic valve opening (start of ejection)

 

Option C. Aortic valve closure (end of ejection)

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and pulse is 105/min. When the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 140 mmHg, the patient's pulse is audible and regular. However, upon inspiration, the pulse disappears and does not reappear until expiration. Only when the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 125 mm Hg is the pulse audible throughout the entire respiratory cycle. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asthma

 

  • The clinical finding described is pulsus paradoxus, a greater than normal (>10 mm Hg) drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.
  • Pulsus paradoxus occurs when the systolic blood pressure falls so much during inspiration that the peripheral pulse disappears with the blood pressure cuff inflated to a certain level.
  • The causes of pulsus paradoxus include asthma, pericardial tamponade, and severe obstructive airway diseases.
  • In asthma, increased negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration exaggerates the normal inspiratory drop in blood pressure, causing pulsus paradoxus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral regurgitation: Does not cause pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option B. Lobar pneumonia: Usually causes fever and lung findings but not pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option C. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Causes outflow obstruction but not pulsus paradoxus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents with a BP of 150/90 mmHg and dizziness. What is the best way to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine

 

  • In a patient with diabetes mellitus and hypertension, first-line antihypertensive therapy often includes calcium channel blockers (such as amlodipine) or ACE inhibitors/ARBs because they effectively manage blood pressure and reduce diabetic kidney disease progression.
  • Amlodipine (a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker) effectively lowers blood pressure and is well tolerated in diabetic patients.
  • Lifestyle modifications remain essential for overall cardiovascular health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Metoprolol  (beta-blocker): Not first-line in diabetes without specific indications such as ischemic heart disease or heart failure; beta-blockers may mask hypoglycemia symptoms.

 

Option B. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification: Insufficient given BP is 150/90 mm Hg, which requires pharmacological intervention.

 

Option C. Diet + Prazosin: Not first-line antihypertensive; generally reserved for resistant cases or specific indications.

 

Thus, combination of lifestyle changes and amlodipine is the best management.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician for a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Water hammer pulse

 

  • The patient's murmur is an early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border, typical of aortic regurgitation (AR).
  • AR causes a water hammer pulse (also called Corrigan's pulse), characterized by a bounding and rapidly collapsing pulse due to rapid systolic ejection and rapid diastolic runoff.
  • Other findings associated with AR include a widened pulse pressure and signs of volume overload.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus parvus et tardus: A slow-rising, weak pulse typical of aortic stenosis.

 

Option B. Pulsus paradoxus: An exaggerated decrease in systolic BP with inspiration, seen in tamponade or severe asthma.

 

Option C. Fixed splitting of S2: Seen in atrial septal defect, not AR.

choices.text: End diastolic volume (EDV) increase, BP decrease, Contractility decrease, HR decrease
End diastolic volume (EDV) decrease, BP decrease, Contractility decrease, HR decrease
End diastolic volume (EDV) increase, BP no change, Contractility increase, HR decrease
End diastolic volume (EDV) decrease, BP increase, Contractility decrease, HR no change

questions.text: A previously healthy 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of chest pain on exertion. She takes no medications. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac stress ECG shows inducible ST-segment depressions in the precordial leads that coincide with the patient's report of chest pain and resolve upon cessation of exercise. Pharmacotherapy with verapamil is initiated. This drug is most likely to have which of the following sets of effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) End diastolic volume (EDV) increase, BP decrease, Contractility decrease, HR decrease

 

  • Verapamil is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It has negative inotropic and chronotropic effects by inhibiting calcium channels in cardiac muscle and the sinoatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes.
  • Effects of verapamil include:
    • Increased end-diastolic volume (EDV): Due to decreased contractility and slower heart rate, allowing more ventricular filling.
    • Decreased blood pressure (BP): Through vasodilation of systemic arteries.
    • Decreased contractility: Negative inotropic effect.
    • Decreased heart rate: Negative chronotropic effect by slowing SA node firing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. End diastolic volume (EDV) decrease, BP decrease, Contractility decrease, HR decrease: EDV decreases with increased contractility, which verapamil decreases.

 

Option C. End diastolic volume (EDV) increase, BP no change, Contractility increase, HR decrease: BP generally decreases due to vasodilation, not increases.

 

Option D. End diastolic volume (EDV) decrease, BP increase, Contractility decrease, HR no change: HR decreases, not stays the same, from verapamil's SA node effects.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with diet and exercise undergoes treadmill stress testing for complaints of intermittent fatigue. He reports no chest pain during the test but stops after 6 minutes due to exertional 

 

  • Vitals:
    • Resting heart rate: 72/min; peak stress heart rate: 138/min
    • Resting blood pressure: 120/75 mm Hg; peak stress: 135/82 mm Hg.
  • ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ischemic changes.
  • Physical exam and echocardiogram at rest are unremarkable.

 

During exercise, which of the following hemodynamic parameters is most likely to be decreased compared to the resting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total systemic vascular resistance

 

During exercise, vasodilation occurs in the skeletal muscles to increase blood flow, which leads to a decrease in total systemic vascular resistance (SVR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac output: Despite decreased SVR, cardiac output increases due to increased heart rate and stroke volume, resulting in increased systolic blood pressure.

 

Option B. Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure: Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure may slightly increase or stay the same due to increased venous return.

 

Option C. Systemic systolic blood pressure: Systemic systolic blood pressure typically increases during exercise due to increased cardiac output.

choices.text: Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 50% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus
Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus
Ruptured atherosclerotic plaque with fully obstructive thrombus
Significant coronary artery vasospasm causing flow obstruction

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to severe central chest pain that started a few hours ago. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and V1–V4, along with deep Q wave formation over the next several hours. Cardiac catheterization would most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured atherosclerotic plaque with fully obstructive thrombus

 

  • The ECG findings show ST elevation in leads I, aVL, and V1–V4 with evolving deep Q waves, consistent with an acute anterolateral ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).
  • Acute STEMI usually results from rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque, leading to thrombus formation that fully obstructs the coronary artery lumen.
  • Cardiac catheterization during acute MI typically reveals a fully occlusive thrombus over a ruptured plaque.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 50% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus and Option B. Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus: Plaques causing 50% or 80% stenosis without thrombus typically cause stable angina or no acute MI.

 

Option D. Significant coronary artery vasospasm causing flow obstruction: Vasospasm causes transient obstruction and usually does not cause persistent ST elevation with Q waves.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is admitted to the hospital due to worsening dyspnea and fatigue. He has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).  The patient is started on oral digoxin for rate control. A week later, his serum digoxin level is measured and found to be markedly elevated, despite receiving an appropriate dose. Upon further questioning, it is discovered that the patient was recently started on amiodarone. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the interaction between the drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of P-glycoprotein

 

  • Amiodarone inhibits P-glycoprotein, a transporter involved in the efflux of digoxin from the kidneys and intestines.
  • Inhibition of P-glycoprotein by amiodarone decreases digoxin clearance, leading to increased serum digoxin levels and a higher risk of digoxin toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blockade of biliary transport proteins: Not involved in digoxin elimination.

 

Option B. Induction of cytochrome P-450 enzymes: Amiodarone is actually an inhibitor, not an inducer, and digoxin is not metabolized significantly by CYP enzymes.

 

Option D. Stimulation of Na+/K+-ATPase: Digoxin inhibits this pump; stimulation would be opposite and unrelated to drug interactions.

choices.text: Increase in a vasomotor centre activity
Increase in the discharge of carotid sinus afferent nerves
Decreased heart rate and blood pressure

questions.text: Below (proximal) the carotid sinus, carotid artery clamping is likely to result in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in a vasomotor centre activity

 

  • Clamping the carotid artery below the carotid sinus reduces blood flow to the sinus baroreceptors, causing decreased baroreceptor firing (afferent nerve discharge).
  • This reduction in baroreceptor signals leads to disinhibition of the vasomotor center in the brainstem, causing increased sympathetic activity to raise heart rate and blood pressure as a compensatory response.
  • Therefore, vasomotor center activity increases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in discharge of carotid sinus afferent nerves: Clamping decreases carotid sinus pressure and thus decreases afferent firing.

 

Option C. Decreased heart rate and blood pressure: Reduced baroreceptor firing stimulates sympathetic outflow, increasing heart rate and BP.

 

Option D. Baroreceptor adaptation: Is a long-term resetting, not an immediate response to arterial clamping.

questions.text: Oxygen sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors are for which of the following ion? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the carotid and aortic bodies that detect changes in blood oxygen levels. These receptors play a critical role in the respiratory control by responding to hypoxia (low oxygen levels). The oxygen-sensitive channels in these receptors are specifically sensitive to potassium ions (K+). When oxygen levels drop, these potassium channels close, which leads to a series of events: membrane depolarization, calcium influx, and ultimately, the release of neurotransmitters like ATP. This process triggers signals that increase respiratory activity to raise blood oxygen levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Sodium channels are important in many physiological processes, but they are not specifically sensitive to oxygen levels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option C. HCO3-: Bicarbonate ions are involved in acid-base balance and CO2 transport but are not directly involved in the oxygen sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions play roles in various cellular processes, including maintaining osmotic balance, but they are not the primary ions involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary ion involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors is potassium (K+). The closure of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels during hypoxia is a crucial step in the signaling pathway that regulates respiratory response to low oxygen levels.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a long history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the clinic complaining of dizziness and weakness in his left arm when performing activities like playing table tennis. He has been a chronic smoker for over 40 years. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, and orthostatic vital signs are normal. A Doppler ultrasound of the left vertebral artery shows retrograde flow instead of normal antegrade flow. Which of the following arteries is most likely stenosed or occluded to cause these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left subclavian artery

 

  • The patient has subclavian steal syndrome, characterized by symptoms of arm ischemia (dizziness and weakness with arm exertion) and retrograde flow in the vertebral artery on Doppler ultrasound.
  • This occurs due to proximal stenosis or occlusion of the left subclavian artery before the origin of the vertebral artery.
  • Blood flow reverses in the ipsilateral vertebral artery to supply the arm, causing vertebrobasilar insufficiency symptoms (dizziness) and arm ischemia during exertion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left internal carotid artery: Causes cerebral ischemia but does not cause retrograde vertebral artery flow.

 

Option B. Left vertebral artery: Occlusion here would reduce vertebral flow but wouldn't cause retrograde flow.

 

Option D. Right subclavian artery: Would cause symptoms on the right side, not left.

choices.text: Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node
Degeneration of the atrioventricular conduction system

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness while playing video games. He states this has occurred intermittently over the past year, but the episodes typically resolve spontaneously after a few minutes. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. ECG is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node

 

  • The patient's presentation of sudden-onset palpitations with intermittent episodes that resolve spontaneously, along with characteristic ECG findings (likely showing short PR interval and delta waves), suggests Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome.
  • WPW is caused by an accessory conduction pathway (bundle of Kent) that bypasses the AV node, allowing premature ventricular activation.
  • This accessory pathway can facilitate a reentrant tachycardia causing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), explaining the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Degeneration of AV conduction system: Typically causes heart block in older patients, not paroxysmal tachycardias in young people.

 

Option C. Ectopic atrial pacemaker activity: Causes atrial tachycardia but does not explain delta waves or WPW ECG pattern.

 

Option D. SA node dysfunction: Causes bradycardia, not tachycardia or reentrant arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2 at 28 weeks is brought to the emergency after being found unconscious at home by her mother. She is disoriented on arrival and her BP is 180/110 mmHg and 4 + proteinuria. On arrival at the emergency, she has a tonic-clonic seizure which resolves with MgSO4 administration. Once the patient is stabilized, she undergoes caesarean delivery for fetal distress. Post-partum, the below MRI is done. What is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

 

  • The case is classic for eclampsia: pregnant woman with hypertension, proteinuria, seizures.
  • The MRI shows bilateral symmetrical areas of hyperintensity in the posterior cerebral hemispheres (parieto-occipital regions), most characteristic of PRES.
  • PRES is associated with eclampsia and presents with headache, altered mental status, seizures, and visual disturbances. MRI usually shows vasogenic edema—seen as high signal in posterior regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hematoma, Option B. Parenchymal hemorrhage, Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Would show focal or diffuse hyperintensity in different locations, not typically as bilateral posterior edema.

questions.text: Which point in the following diagram indicates that the left ventricular pressure is equivalent to the diastolic blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) b

 

  • On the left ventricular pressure-volume loop, point b indicates the point where the aortic valve opens. This occurs when left ventricular pressure first exceeds the aortic (diastolic) pressure, allowing ejection to begin.
  • Thus, at point b, left ventricular pressure is equal to the diastolic blood pressure of the aorta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. a: Mitral valve closes (end-diastolic volume, start of systole)

 

Option C. c: Aortic valve closes (end-systolic volume)

 

Option D. d: Mitral valve opens (start of ventricular filling)

choices.text: Rupture of sinus of Valsalva aneurysm

questions.text: The following pattern of murmur is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VSD with aortic regurgitation

 

  • The murmur pattern in the image is a continuous murmur, meaning it is present throughout both systole and diastole (between S1 and S2, and after S2). Classic conditions that produce a continuous murmur include:
    • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
    • Coronary arteriovenous (AV) fistula
    • Rupture of sinus of Valsalva aneurysm
  • VSD with aortic regurgitation produces two separate murmurs—a pansystolic murmur for VSD, and a diastolic murmur for aortic regurgitation—but not a continuous murmur throughout the cardiac cycle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure, with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide

 

  • The patient has NYHA class III heart failure with signs of congestion (dyspnea, pedal edema).
  • Elevated potassium (5.5 mg%) indicates hyperkalemia, which contraindicates or limits the use of drugs that increase potassium levels, such as:
    • Spironolactone (potassium-sparing diuretic)
    • Enalapril (ACE inhibitor causes potassium retention)
  • Digoxin is used cautiously and does not address volume overload.
  • Furosemide (a loop diuretic) effectively reduces fluid overload and does not increase potassium levels; it can help reduce symptoms without worsening hyperkalemia.

 

Thus, furosemide is the safest choice for this patient with heart failure and hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z in a 45-year old Indian man?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Waist circumference of 88cm

 

  • Syndrome Z refers to the coexistence of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) with metabolic syndrome.
  • Metabolic syndrome components include:
    • Elevated blood pressure (≥130/85 mm Hg or on treatment)
    • High fasting triglycerides (≥150 mg/dL)
    • Increased waist circumference (for South Asians, cutoff is typically ≥90 cm for men)
  • This patient has blood pressure of 145/89 mm Hg and triglycerides of 160 mg/dL, both fitting the criteria.
  • Waist circumference of 88 cm is below the typical cutoff for Indian men, so this is not a component meeting the criteria.

 

Therefore, waist circumference of 88 cm is not a component of Syndrome Z in this patient.The correct answer is C) Waist circumference of 88 cm.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the bradycardia seen in Cushing reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Baroreceptor activation 

 

  • The Cushing reflex occurs in response to increased intracranial pressure (ICP), which leads to cerebral ischemia.
  • Increased ICP causes a sympathetic surge to raise blood pressure (hypertension) to maintain cerebral perfusion.
  • The elevated blood pressure activates the baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch.
  • Baroreceptor activation triggers a reflex parasympathetic response, leading to bradycardia despite the sympathetic drive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart failure: Not related to Cushing reflex bradycardia.

 

Option C. Cardiac conduction defect: Not relevant to this reflex.

 

Option D. Increased activity of RVLM (rostral ventrolateral medulla): RVLM mediates sympathetic outflow causing hypertension and tachycardia, not bradycardia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg on the left arm and 162/90 mm Hg on the right arm. He reports that he is adherent with his medication and exercise regimen. The physician adds a drug to his antihypertensive medication regimen. This drug increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels, and decreases serum aldosterone levels, without affecting bradykinin levels. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candesartan

 

  • The drug described increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels but decreases aldosterone levels without affecting bradykinin.
  • Candesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). ARBs block the angiotensin II receptor, leading to decreased aldosterone production.
  • Because they block the receptor but not the production of angiotensin II, levels of renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II increase due to feedback.
  • ARBs do not inhibit bradykinin breakdown, so bradykinin levels remain unchanged.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aliskiren: Direct renin inhibitor; lowers renin and downstream angiotensins.

 

Option C. Verapamil: Calcium channel blocker; does not affect renin-angiotensin system.

 

Option D. Lisinopril: ACE inhibitor; increases bradykinin levels by blocking its degradation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. An ECG was taken in the emergency and was shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior MI

 

The patient's ECG shows classic signs of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI). The characteristic features of posterior MI in leads V1, V2 and (±) V3 include a tall R wave, ST depression, and upright T wave. These features suggest a mirror image of an infarction in the posterior wall of the left ventricle. While definitive diagnosis of a posterior MI typically involves additional leads (V7, V8, V9), the observed patterns in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of this condition.

 

In the provided case, the absence of ST elevation rules out an acute STEMI. NSTEMI and unstable angina can only be differentiated by cardiac biomarkers such as troponins, which are not mentioned here. Acute myocarditis would typically present with non-specific ECG changes and a relevant clinical history, such as a recent viral infection, which is not present in this scenario.

 

  • The ECG shows:
    • ST segment depression in leads V1 to V3
    • Tall, broad R waves in V1–V3
    • Upright T waves in these leads

 

This pattern is the mirror image (reciprocal changes) of ST elevation MI seen in the posterior wall, as the standard precordial leads (V1–V3) "look through" the anterior wall. Posterior MI does not directly produce ST elevation on the standard 12-lead ECG, but instead these characteristic reciprocal changes.

 

  • NSTEMI and unstable angina may show ST depression or T wave changes but do not have prominent R waves in V1–V3.
  • Acute myocarditis can mimic MI but seldom presents with this classic pattern.

 

Thus, the ECG is diagnostic of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with box car nuclei seen on histopathological examination of the myocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertensive cardiomyopathy 

 

  • The image shows "boxcar nuclei"—enlarged, rectangular, polygonal nuclei seen in cardiac myocytes.
  • Boxcar nuclei are typically found in ventricular myocytes exposed to chronic pressure overload, most commonly due to systemic hypertension (hypertensive cardiomyopathy).
  • Chronic hypertension leads to left ventricular hypertrophy, with characteristic nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia (boxcar appearance) as myocytes hypertrophy to compensate for increased afterload.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive cardiomyopathy and Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: May show different histopathological changes, but boxcar nuclei are not characteristic.

 

Option D. Subendocardial ischemia: Does not typically cause boxcar nuclei.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting and seizures. On examination blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Labetalol

 

  • The patient has a hypertensive emergency with signs of hypertensive encephalopathy (headache, confusion, seizures, visual disturbances) and very high blood pressure (220/110 mm Hg).
  • In hypertensive emergencies, intravenous antihypertensives with rapid onset but controlled lowering of blood pressure are required.
  • IV Labetalol is a commonly used, effective agent that lowers BP quickly without significant cerebral blood flow reduction.
  • Oral agents like nifedipine or nicardipine capsules are too slow or inappropriate for emergencies.
  • IV nitroglycerin mainly dilates veins and is generally used for acute coronary syndrome or pulmonary edema, not primary hypertensive encephalopathy.

 

Thus, IV labetalol is the most appropriate choice.The correct answer is A. Cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of breathlessness on walking a few metres. He adds that he has an uncomfortable awareness of his heartbeat, especially on lying down. Examination reveals widened pulse pressure and pulsating uvula. Which of the following would be the most likely auscultatory finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Austin Flint murmur

 

  • The patient’s symptoms of breathlessness on exertion, widened pulse pressure, and pulsating uvula are classic signs of aortic regurgitation (AR).
  • The Austin Flint murmur is a low-pitched, mid-to-late diastolic rumbling murmur heard best at the cardiac apex in AR.
  • It is produced by the regurgitant jet from the aorta impinging on the anterior mitral leaflet, causing functional mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carey Coombs murmur: Mid-diastolic murmur due to mitral valve inflammation in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Gallavardin phenomenon: Murmur of aortic stenosis radiating to the apex, sometimes mistaken for mitral regurgitation.

 

Option D. Graham Steel murmur: A high-pitched, early diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation due to pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? 

 

Management

  1. Beta-blockers are given
  2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated
  3. ICD is indicated
  4. ICD is contraindicated

 

Clinical findings

  1. Pulsus bisferiens
  2. Pulsus alternans
  3. Ejection systolic murmur
  4. Murmur increases on standing
  5. Murmur decreases on standing
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

  • The clinical scenario describes hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):
    • ECG shows T-wave inversions in V5, V6.
    • 2D Echo shows systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve.
    • The patient collapsed while playing sports, raising concern for arrhythmias or sudden cardiac death risk.

 

Clinical findings in HCM:

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a double-peaked carotid pulse) is classic.
  • Ejection systolic murmur due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.
  • The murmur increases on standing (due to decreased preload, increased obstruction).

 

Management:

 

  • Beta-blockers are given to reduce heart rate and improve diastolic filling.
  • ICD (implantable cardioverter defibrillator) is indicated for sudden cardiac death prevention in high-risk patients with HCM.

 

Other options are incorrect because beta-blockers are not contraindicated in HCM, and ICD is indicated, not contraindicated.

 

Thus, the appropriate combination is 1 & 3; a, c, d.

choices.text: ↑ PCWP, ↓ CI (cardiac index), ↑ SVR, ↓ SvO2

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman with poorly controlled diabetes presents with fever, dysuria, and right flank pain. BP is 80/44 mmHg, pulse 134/min. Serum glucose is 72 mg/dL, urine ketones positive. Neck veins are flat. Which of the following hemodynamic parameters are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ↓ PCWP, ↑ CI, ↓ SVR, ↑ SvO2

 

  • The patient presents with signs of septic shock: fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and signs of infection.
  • Early septic shock is characterized by:
    • Decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR) due to vasodilation.
    • Increased cardiac index (CI) due to compensatory hyperdynamic circulation.
    • Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) as a result of peripheral vasodilation and relative hypovolemia.
    • Increased mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) because tissues extract less oxygen due to abnormal oxygen utilization or shunting.

 

Other options do not fit the hemodynamic profile of early septic shock.

 

Therefore, the hemodynamic parameters are decreased PCWP, increased CI, decreased SVR, and increased SvO2.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true of the baroreceptor reflex pathway?

 

  1. Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is inhibited by CVLM. 
  2. Caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) releases GABA.
  3. Nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) releases GABA.
  4. Stretch receptors are stimulated by increased blood pressure
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

 

In the baroreceptor reflex pathway:

 

1. The rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM), which drives sympathetic outflow, is inhibited by the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) during increased blood pressure to reduce sympathetic tone.

 

2. The CVLM releases GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter that suppresses the RVLM.

 

4. Stretch receptors (baroreceptors) are stimulated by increased blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

3. The nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) primarily receives afferent input from baroreceptors and is primarily excitatory, not generally releasing GABA.

choices.text: Splenectomy is considered after glucocorticoid therapy failure
IVIG is a treatment option in life-threatening bleeding
Romiplostim and eltrombopag are avoided post-splenectomy
Rh(D) immune globulin is used in Rh-positive patients

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the management of Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Romiplostim and eltrombopag are avoided post-splenectomy

 

  • In Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP):
    • Splenectomy is considered for patients who do not respond to glucocorticoid therapy.
    • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is used in life-threatening bleeding to rapidly increase platelet count.
    • Rh(D) immune globulin is used in Rh-positive patients to treat ITP.
  • Romiplostim and eltrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonists used to stimulate platelet production and are not contraindicated after splenectomy; in fact, they can be used in refractory cases regardless of splenectomy status.

questions.text: A 18-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with a 2-week history of rapidly increasing swelling on his jaw, recurrent nosebleeds, weight loss, and generalized fatigue. Physical examination of the neck reveals firm, nontender lymph nodes. The mass is biopsied, the image is shown below. Which of the following best describes the genomic structure of the most likely causative virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double-stranded linear DNA

 

  • This patient’s presentation, including rapid swelling of lymph nodes, recurrent nosebleeds, weight loss, and fatigue, is concerning for lymphoma, particularly Burkitt lymphoma. 
  • Burkitt lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), a virus with a double-stranded linear DNA genome. 
  • EBV is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of several lymphoproliferative diseases, including Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Double-stranded circular DNA: This is characteristic of certain viruses like the herpesvirus family (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus), but Epstein-Barr virus specifically has a linear double-stranded DNA genome, not circular.

 

Option C. Double-stranded linear RNA: Double-stranded RNA viruses are found in families like reoviruses, but they are not associated with Burkitt lymphoma or the Epstein-Barr virus.

 

Option D. Single-stranded linear RNA: Single-stranded RNA viruses (e.g., influenza virus, HIV) are not associated with Burkitt lymphoma, which is linked to EBV, a DNA virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most likely causative virus for this patient’s symptoms is Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which has a double-stranded linear DNA genome. 
  • EBV is associated with Burkitt lymphoma and other lymphoproliferative disorders.

choices.text: Reduced R-time, increased angle, increased MA, increased LY30
Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, decreased LY30
Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, increased LY30
Reduced R-time, decreased angle, increased MA, decreased LY30

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sepsis and purpura fulminans. Thromboelastography (TEG) is ordered to assess the patient's clotting profile. Which of the following TEG tracings is most consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, increased LY30

 

  • The patient with sepsis and purpura fulminans is likely experiencing disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • In DIC, thromboelastography (TEG) typically shows:
    • Prolonged R-time: due to coagulation factor consumption leading to delayed clot initiation.
    • Increased angle: fibrinolysis may initially cause rapid clot formation before consumption.
    • Decreased maximum amplitude (MA): due to platelet dysfunction or decreased platelet count.
    • Increased LY30: indicating increased fibrinolysis and clot breakdown.

 

Other tracings do not fit the complex coagulopathy seen in sepsis-induced DIC with purpura fulminans.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman with a long history of menorrhagia comes to the physician due to a low hemoglobin level identified on routine laboratory evaluation. She is diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia and started on oral ferrous sulfate. Which of the following cells secrete a substance that controls iron storage and release by other cells involved in iron homeostasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatic parenchymal cells

 

  • Hepatic parenchymal cells (hepatocytes) secrete hepcidin, a key hormone that regulates systemic iron homeostasis.
  • Hepcidin controls iron storage and release by binding to ferroportin on enterocytes (intestinal cells), macrophages, and hepatocytes, causing its internalization and degradation.
  • Therefore, hepatic parenchymal cells are responsible for secreting the iron-regulating hormone hepcidin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biliary lining cells: Not involved in iron regulation.

 

Option B. Bone marrow macrophages: Involved in iron recycling but do not secrete hepcidin.

 

Option C. Enterocytes: Absorb iron but do not regulate iron homeostasis by hormone secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocytes (hepatic parenchymal cells) secrete hepcidin, a key hormone regulating iron homeostasis. Hepcidin controls iron storage and release by binding to ferroportin on enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes to regulate iron absorption and recycling. Other options are not involved in secreting the substance that controls iron storage and release.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician with jaundice and pallor. He was adopted and his family history is unknown. Laboratory studies show anemia, reticulocytosis, and increased indirect bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear is shown. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased MCHC

 

  • The patient's presentation of anemia, reticulocytosis, increased indirect bilirubin, and the peripheral smear showing spherocytes suggests hereditary spherocytosis.
  • In hereditary spherocytosis, red blood cells are sphere-shaped and have increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) due to decrease in cell surface area.
  • Additional findings typically include:
    • Decreased haptoglobin (not increased) due to hemolysis.
    • Increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) (not decreased) from cell breakdown.
    • Negative Coombs test because it's a hereditary membrane defect, not autoimmune hemolysis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman with warfarin induced bleeding receives IV vitamin K, 4 U PRBCs and 4U FFP. 4h later, she begins to complain of shortness of breath. Vitals T - 39°C, RR 35/min, SpO2 84% on RA, and BP 88/52 mm Hg. Exam revealed B/L crackles and the patient was intubated for respiratory failure. CXR is as shown in the picture. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TRALI

 

  • The patient developed acute respiratory distress (dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachypnea, hypotension) and bilateral crackles within 6 hours of receiving multiple blood product transfusions.
  • Chest X-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates.
  • TRALI is characterized by non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema occurring within 6 hours of transfusion, with fever, hypoxemia, and no evidence of circulatory overload or cardiac dysfunction.
  • Key features differentiating TRALI from TACO (Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload) include the presence of fever, hypotension (rather than hypertension), and absence of signs of fluid overload or elevated jugular venous pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylaxis: Presents with hypotension but is typically accompanied by urticaria, angioedema, and wheezing rather than isolated bilateral infiltrates.

 

Option B. TACO: Presents with signs of volume overload (hypertension, elevated JVP, S3) and usually no fever.

 

Option D. Aspiration: Would not be closely linked to recent transfusion and less likely to cause diffuse bilateral infiltrates so rapidly.

choices.text: Inability to produce beta globin chains
Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

questions.text:
7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He underwent a splenectomy a year ago for persistent anemia and jaundice. He has received the pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccinations and takes penicillin prophylaxis. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing child. The sclerae are anicteric. The abdomen is soft and nontender; no masses are palpable. Several well-healed laparoscopy scars are noted. Complete blood count is as follows:

 

Hemoglobin: 11.3 g/dL

 

Reticulocytes: 3%

 

Platelets: 160,000/mm³

 

Leukocytes: 8,200/mm³

 

Peripheral blood smear with Wright stain is shown.

 

 

This patient's findings are most likely related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

 

  • The child had a splenectomy for persistent anemia and jaundice, with a peripheral smear that likely shows Howell-Jolly bodies, which are nuclear remnants (DNA fragments) in red blood cells.
  • Howell-Jolly bodies appear due to the absence of splenic function, as the spleen normally filters out these nuclear remnants.
  • This persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei in circulating erythrocytes explains the patient’s findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Hb oxidation and precipitation: Seen in conditions like G6PD deficiency or unstable hemoglobin disorders, leading to Heinz bodies.

 

Option B. Inability to produce beta globin chains: Causes beta-thalassemia, showing microcytic anemia and target cells.

 

Option C. Mechanical RBC membrane damage: Seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (e.g., schistocytes), not post-splenectomy.

 

Therefore, the findings are due to persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei after splenectomy.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother due to leg pain. One week ago mother saw the patient fall onto the living room floor after climbing on a couch. Since the incident, she has had persistent leg pain that appears to be worse at night, and for the last 2 days she has been refusing to walk asking her mother to carry her. The patient has no chronic medical conditions but has had a mild, non-productive cough for the past month. Temperature is 38.3 C (100.9 F); all other vital signs are normal.  Examination shows a pale child. The abdomen is nontender and moderate hepatosplenomegaly is noted. Palpation of the bilateral anterior proximal tibias elicits pain. There are a few scattered bruises across the chest and back. Complete blood count results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin-8g/dL

 

Platelets-30,000/mm³

 

Leukocytes-3,000/mm³

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Iymphoblastic leukemia

 

  • The child presents with leg pain worsening at night, refusal to walk, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, bruising, and cytopenias (anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia).
  • These signs suggest bone marrow infiltration and failure.
  • ALL is the most common childhood cancer and presents with bone pain, cytopenias, and systemic symptoms.
  • Mild cough and fever may be related to immunosuppression.
  • Aplastic anemia typically presents with pancytopenia without organomegaly or bone pain.
  • Immune thrombocytopenia causes isolated thrombocytopenia with bruising but no marrow failure signs or hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Infectious mononucleosis is less likely to cause cytopenias of this severity or bone pain.

 

Thus, the presentation is most consistent with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns of appearing pale. Over the past few days, he has been sleeping more than usual and is less interactive.  He continues to have good urine output. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation and had a normal nursery course. However, the patient's newborn screen revealed an extra band representing gamma tetramers on haemoglobin electrophoresis. The patient takes a vitamin D supplement daily. Vital signs are normal. He appears tired and has mild scleral icterus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) HbH disease

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for persistent lower back pain and fatigue. Laboratory testing shows anemia and renal dysfunction. Serum electrophoresis of the serum proteins is shown below. A medication that blocks cellular proteasome action is administered. This treatment is most likely to cause which of the following effects on the abnormal cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased apoptosis 

 

The patient's findings (persistent back pain, anemia, renal dysfunction) and the serum protein electrophoresis image showing a prominent gamma spike (M protein) are classic for multiple myeloma.

 

Proteasome inhibitors (like bortezomib) are used to treat multiple myeloma. They block the proteasome pathway, causing accumulation of misfolded proteins, which triggers cellular stress and leads to increased apoptosis of the malignant plasma cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Augmented cytotoxic T-cell response: Not the main effect of proteasome inhibition in multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. Decreased DNA methylation and Option C. Impaired RNA splicing: Not the mechanism targeted by proteasome inhibitors.

 

Therefore, treatment with a proteasome inhibitor causes increased apoptosis of abnormal myeloma cells.

choices.text: Autoimmune-induced loss of self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells
Bone marrow replacement by constitutively active tyrosine kinase-stimulated cells
Splenic hyperactivity with cell trapping by the reticuloendothelial system
