Ineffective hematopoiesis secondary to micronutrient deficiency

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman come to the emergency department due to bloody stools. For the past month, she has also had decreased energy.  Skin examination shows pallor and scattered bruises in various stages of healing throughout the trunk. The abdomen is soft without organomegaly. Complete blood count results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin: 7.2 g/dL

 

Mean corpuscular volume: 90 um³

 

Platelets: 10,000/mm²

 

Leukocytes: 1050/mm³

 

Neutrophils: 5%

 

Lymphocytes: 95%

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patients condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autoimmune-induced loss of self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells

 

  • The patient presents with pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia), bruising, and bleeding, which suggests bone marrow failure.
  • The normal MCV and lack of organomegaly argue against micronutrient deficiency or splenic sequestration.
  • The finding of severe leukopenia with lymphocyte predominance supports an immune-mediated process.
  • Aplastic anemia is caused by autoimmune destruction or suppression of self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells, resulting in pancytopenia with a hypocellular marrow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bone marrow replacement by constitutively active tyrosine kinase-stimulated cells: Bone marrow replacement by constitutively active tyrosine kinase cells occurs in chronic myeloid leukemia, which doesn’t present with pancytopenia and lymphocytosis.

 

Option C. Splenic hyperactivity with cell trapping by the reticuloendothelial system: Splenic hyperactivity causes cytopenias but is usually associated with splenomegaly.

 

Option D. Ineffective hematopoiesis secondary to micronutrient deficiency: Micronutrient deficiency leads to ineffective hematopoiesis but usually causes macrocytosis or other characteristic blood changes.

choices.text: Diffusely fibrotic marrow with clusters of megakaryocytes
Increased staining for storage iron in marrow macrophages
Marrow replaced by dysplastic cells of all 3 lineages
Severely hypocellular marrow replaced by adipose cells

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the OPD with a few months of severe fatigue and a 6.8-kg unintentional loss in weight. Abdominal examination shows mild hepatomegaly and a markedly enlarged spleen. Stool guaiac testing is negative. Laboratory results show pancytopenia, and peripheral blood smear is shown below. Bone marrow aspiration is attempted but yields no marrow, and a bone marrow biopsy is subsequently performed. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed in this patient's bone marrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diffusely fibrotic marrow with clusters of megakaryocytes 

 

  • The patient’s presentation of severe fatigue, weight loss, hepatomegaly, markedly enlarged spleen, pancytopenia, and a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration is characteristic of primary myelofibrosis.
  • In primary myelofibrosis, bone marrow biopsy shows diffuse fibrosis with increased reticulin and collagen deposition, often accompanied by clusters of atypical megakaryocytes.
  • The fibrosis leads to marrow failure and extramedullary hematopoiesis, causing splenomegaly and hepatomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased staining for storage iron in marrow macrophages: seen in iron overload or sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Marrow replaced by dysplastic cells of all 3 lineages: Seen in myelodysplastic syndromes.

 

Option D. Severely hypocellular marrow replaced by adipose cells: Typical of aplastic anemia.

questions.text:
35-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of weakness, fatigue, and pallor. Physical examination is unremarkable except for conjunctival pallor. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Haemoglobin: 7.2 g/dL

 

Mean corpuscular volume: 90 fL

 

Reticulocytes: 0.1%

 

Platelets: 280,000 /uL

 

Leukocyte count: 6,700 cells/uL

 

Iron studies and serum B12 and folic acid levels are within normal limits. Bone marrow biopsy shows absence of erythroid precursors but preserved myeloid and megakaryocytic elements. Further workup would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymic tumor

 

  • The patient has pure red cell aplasia (PRCA), characterized by anemia with low reticulocyte count, normal white blood cells and platelets, and bone marrow showing absent erythroid precursors but preserved myeloid and megakaryocytic lineages.
  • PRCA can be secondary to thymoma (thymic tumor), an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies or T cells suppress erythroid precursors.
  • Other malignancies listed are not commonly associated with PRCA.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Primarily causes anemia through chronic disease or bleeding but is not commonly associated with pure red cell aplasia or selective erythroid precursor absence.

 

Option B. Renal cell carcinoma: Known for producing erythropoietin and causing polycythemia rather than anemia; it is not typically linked with isolated red cell aplasia.

 

Option D. Cerebellar hemangioblastoma: Associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease and can lead to polycythemia due to ectopic erythropoietin production, not isolated anemia or red cell aplasia.

 

The image below shows THYMUS TUMOR on CT [likely suggestive of THYMOMA]

questions.text: Supravital stain of a peripheral smear of a patient is shown. What is the likely inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) X-linked recessive inheritance 

 

The image shows a red blood cell with a blue-stained inclusion, most likely a Heinz body, seen with supravital staining. Heinz bodies suggest underlying G6PD deficiency, which leads to the formation of these inclusions when red cells are under oxidative stress.

 

G6PD deficiency follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A 54-year-old previously healthy man comes to the OPD due to several weeks of leg swelling. He has had no fever, chest pain, or dyspnea. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. A mobile left flank mass can be palpated. There are several vertically oriented tortuous veins on the lower abdominal wall. Which of the following structures is most likely obstructed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior vena cava

 

  • The patient has leg swelling, a mobile left flank mass (likely a renal mass), and vertically oriented tortuous veins on the lower abdominal wall.
  • These superficial veins suggest collateral circulation due to obstruction of the inferior vena cava (IVC), which causes blood to be diverted through superficial abdominal veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral veins and Option B. Iliac veins: Obstruction of femoral or iliac veins would typically cause unilateral leg swelling without prominent abdominal wall veins.

 

Option D. Portal vein: Portal vein obstruction leads to portal hypertension and dilated veins around the umbilicus (caput medusae), which are radiating veins, not vertical.

questions.text:
Part 2 of 2

Further evaluation of the patient reveals microscopic hematuria. Laboratory results are as follows:

Leukocytes: 9,000/mm³

Hemoglobin: 19.2 g/dL

Platelets: 230,000/mm³

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hematologic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Excess erythropoietin production

 

  • The patient has leg swelling, a left flank mass, microscopic hematuria, and a very high hemoglobin (19.2 g/dL).
  • These findings suggest a renal cell carcinoma (RCC), which often produces ectopic erythropoietin, leading to secondary polycythemia (elevated hemoglobin).
  • Microscopic hematuria and a palpable flank mass are classic signs of RCC.
  • The elevated hemoglobin is due to excess erythropoietin production by the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arteriovenous malformation: May cause hematuria but not typically polycythemia.

 

Option C. Extramedullary hematopoiesis: Occurs in chronic marrow failure states, not typically with hematuria or flank masses.

 

Option D. Myeloproliferative disorder: Can cause polycythemia but does not explain the flank mass or hematuria.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the OPD due to 3 months of progressive fatigue and back pain. The back pain occurs mainly with movement or positional changes. Physical examination reveals midline tenderness over the middle and lower back. Laboratory evaluation shows a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL and serum calcium level of 12 mg/dL. A bone marrow aspirate is performed, and the histopathologic findings are shown below. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amyloidosis

 

  • The patient's symptoms (progressive fatigue, back pain with movement, midline spinal tenderness), laboratory findings (anemia, hypercalcemia), and the bone marrow aspirate (showing numerous plasma cells) are classic for multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy that produces large amounts of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains.
  • These light chains can deposit in various tissues, leading to amyloidosis (specifically AL amyloidosis), causing organ dysfunction.
  • Amyloidosis is a well-known complication in patients with multiple myeloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardiac tamponade and Option D. Hyperthyroidism: They are not directly related to multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Hepatic failure: Hepatic failure can occur in advanced disease but is not a common or primary risk compared to amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is being evaluated for nontender cervical lymphadenopathy that he first noticed while shaving. A biopsy is performed and is shown below. Cytogenetic analysis would most likely demonstrate which of the following patterns?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BCL-2 overexpression

 

  • The clinical presentation of nontender cervical lymphadenopathy in a young adult and the biopsy (likely showing a follicular pattern) suggests follicular lymphoma.
  • Follicular lymphoma is characterized by the t(14;18) translocation, which leads to overexpression of the BCL-2 protein.
  • BCL-2 overexpression prevents apoptosis, allowing neoplastic follicular center cells to survive longer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BCR-ABL rearrangement (Philadelphia chromosome): Seen in chronic myeloid leukemia.

 

Option C. C-MYC overexpression: Seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Option D. Constitutive tyrosine kinase activation: Typically associated with myeloproliferative disorders and CML.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to prolonged epistaxis. The girl says that she picked her nose immediately before the bleeding started. Her parents decided to take her to the emergency department after the epistaxis persisted for 20 minutes despite constant compression.  The patient has had frequent nosebleeds that often last >10 minutes. Laboratory tests are ordered, and results are as follows:

 

Hematocrit: 43%

 

Bleeding time: prolonged

 

Partial thromboplastin time (PTT): prolonged

 

Prothrombin time (PT): normal

 

Thrombin time (TT): normal

 

D-dimer: normal

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) von Willebrand disease 

 

  • The patient presents with prolonged bleeding time and prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), but with normal prothrombin time (PT) and normal thrombin time (TT), consistent with a defect in the intrinsic pathway.
  • von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and causes defective platelet adhesion, leading to prolonged bleeding time.
  • vWD also causes prolonged PTT because von Willebrand factor stabilizes factor VIII; its deficiency decreases factor VIII levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XIll deficiency: Factor XIII deficiency causes normal coagulation tests but abnormal wound healing and bleeding.

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: Hemophilia A causes prolonged PTT but normal bleeding time.

 

Option C. Vitamin K deficiency: The normal PT differentiates it from vitamin K deficiency, which prolongs both PT and PTT.

questions.text: Which of the following is useful for a patient having Haemophilia B?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fresh frozen plasma

 

  • Hemophilia B is caused by a deficiency of factor IX.
  • Fresh frozen plasma contains all clotting factors, including factor IX, making it useful for treating hemophilia B when factor IX concentrate is not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoprecipitate: Cryoprecipitate contains mostly factor VIII, fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor, and factor XIII, but very little factor IX, so it is not useful in hemophilia B.

 

Option C. Recombinant factor 8: Recombinant factor VIII is specifically for hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency).

 

Option D. Cryo poor plasma: Cryo-poor plasma (plasma minus cryoprecipitate) contains factors not in cryoprecipitate but is not typically used to treat hemophilia B.

choices.text: Induction of conformational change in antithrombin III
Reduced activation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of palpitations and shortness of breath that started 3 days ago. She has hypertension and congestive heart failure. An ECG shows a narrow-complex tachycardia without P waves. The patient is prescribed a prophylactic medication that can be reversed with idarucizumab. The expected beneficial effect of the prescribed drug is most likely due to which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Direct inhibition of thrombin

 

  • The patient presents with atrial fibrillation (narrow-complex tachycardia without P waves), for which anticoagulation is required to prevent thromboembolism.
  • The medication mentioned is one that can be reversed with idarucizumab, which is a specific antidote for dabigatran.
  • Dabigatran is a direct thrombin (factor IIa) inhibitor, providing anticoagulation.
  • Other anticoagulants

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Induction of conformational change in antithrombin III: It is the mechanism of heparin.

 

Option B. Direct inhibition of factor Xa: Direct inhibition of factor Xa corresponds to drugs like rivaroxaban, apixaban.

 

Option C. Reduced activation of factors II, VII, IX, and X: It is the mechanism of warfarin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the calorimetric test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

  • The RBC pipette is used for counting or measuring red blood cells and platelets counting, not for hemoglobin estimation.
  • The Sahli graduated hemoglobin tube, hemoglobin pipette, and comparator with brown glass standard are all components used in the Sahli’s method for hemoglobin estimation by calorimetric (colorimetric) test.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the changes that occur in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve of different types of hemoglobin under various conditions. The blood obtained from a male infant shows decreased affinity for 2,3-bisphosphoglyceric acid. Which of the following is the most likely composition of the hemoglobin molecule in this sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) α2y2

 

  • The blood is from a male infant, and the hemoglobin present in infants is primarily fetal hemoglobin (HbF).
  • HbF consists of two alpha (α) and two gamma (γ) globin chains (α2γ2).
  • HbF has decreased affinity for 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) compared to adult hemoglobin, which increases its oxygen affinity and facilitates oxygen transfer from mother to fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. α2β2: Adult hemoglobin (HbA), which has higher affinity for 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. β4: Hemoglobin H disease (HbH), composed of β4 chains.

 

Option D. α2δ2: Hemoglobin A2, a minor component of adult hemoglobin.

questions.text: A 25 yr old women G2P1L1 is brought to the emergency at 30 weeks gestation in active labor. The patient had severe anemia during pregnancy and received multiple blood transfusions during past months. An uncomplicated Vaginal delivery is performed and 2.5 kg infant is delivered. Post operatively she continues to bleed and receives a transfusion of 1 unit of packed RBC. One hour later, the patient appears to have flank pain and in acute distress. Temperature is 101°F, pulse 115/min and BP is 92/66 mm Hg. Foley catheter shows dark brown urine. Further evaluation is most likely to show:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Positive Direct Coomb’s

 

  • The patient developed symptoms of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (fever, flank pain, hypotension, dark brown urine shortly after transfusion).
  • This reaction is usually due to antibodies against red blood cell antigens from a previous sensitization, causing immune-mediated destruction of transfused RBCs.
  • The Direct Coombs test (direct antiglobulin test) detects antibodies or complement bound to RBCs and would be positive in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum antibodies against Class 1 HLA: Serum antibodies against Class 1 HLA are associated with febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions, not acute hemolysis.

 

Option C. B/L pulmonary infiltrates on CXR: Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates indicate transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), a different complication.

 

Option D. Low levels of serum IgA: Low serum IgA is related to anaphylactic transfusion reactions in IgA-deficient patients, which present differently.

choices.text: Saline washed RBC: Increased risk of allergic reaction

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cryo-poor plasma: TTP 

 

  • Cryo-poor plasma (cryosupernatant) is plasma from which cryoprecipitate has been removed. It contains ADAMTS13 enzyme and is used in the treatment of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) to replenish ADAMTS13 and correct the deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FFP: Hemophilia A: Hemophilia A is treated with factor VIII concentrate or cryoprecipitate, not FFP routinely.

 

Option B. Saline washed RBC: Increased risk of allergic reaction: Washing reduces allergic reactions, so they lower, not increase, the risk.

 

Option C. Cryoprecipitate: Hemophilia B: Hemophilia B (factor IX deficiency) requires factor IX concentrate or FFP, not cryoprecipitate.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure often seen in aplastic anemia, involves the failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells. The spleen is not involved in this pathology, so splenectomy would not be beneficial. The problem lies within the bone marrow, not the spleen, making splenectomy contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic rupture: Splenectomy is commonly indicated in cases of splenic rupture, whether due to trauma or iatrogenic causes, to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: In cases of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), splenectomy can be an effective treatment option to achieve durable remission, although it is not the first-line treatment.

 

  • Corticosteroids and other treatments are often tried first.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: Splenectomy may be indicated in hairy cell leukemia in cases of massive splenomegaly or persistent cytopenias to alleviate symptoms and improve blood counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to fatigue, easy bruising, and frequent nosebleeds for 2 weeks. On physical examination, the child appears pale with scattered petechiae. Laboratory studies show:

 

Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL

 

Platelet count: 21,000/mm³

 

Leukocyte count: 15,500/mm³

 

A bone marrow aspirate reveals the findings shown in the image below. The cells are positive for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and express CD19 and CD10. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Precursor B-cell leukemia 

 

  • The child's symptoms (fatigue, bruising, nosebleeds), laboratory findings (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis), and bone marrow aspirate indicate acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
  • Positivity for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and expression of CD19 and CD10 are characteristic markers of precursor B-cell ALL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Precursor T-cell leukemia: Precursor T-cell leukemia expresses markers like CD3 and lacks CD19.

 

Option C. Mature B-cell leukemia and D. Mature T-cell leukemia: Mature B-cell or T-cell leukemias would not express TdT.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 5 cm below the costal margin. Her leukocyte count is 12,000/mm 3 and platelet count is 217,000/mm 3. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Smudge cells

 

  • The patient has painless lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, mild leukocytosis, and normal platelets, a presentation suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
  • Peripheral blood smear in CLL characteristically shows smudge cells, which are fragile, broken leukocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ringed sideroblasts: Seen in sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option B. Teardrop cells: Associated with myelofibrosis and marrow infiltration.

 

Option D. Rouleaux formation: Seen in multiple myeloma, characterized by stacked red blood cells.

choices.text: Increased direct to total bilirubin ratio

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of yellowing of his eyes. He has also noticed a decrease in his exercise capacity and gets quickly exhausted after minor physical activity. Examination shows scleral icterus and pale mucous membranes. He has splenomegaly. His hemoglobin concentration is 7.9 mg/dL, leukocyte count 8500/mm³ and platelet count is 1.8 lakhs/mm3. Direct antiglobulin and heterophile antibody tests are positive. Which of the following additional laboratory findings are most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased haptoglobin levels

 

  • The patient has scleral icterus, anemia, splenomegaly, and positive direct antiglobulin (Coombs) and heterophile antibody tests. This indicates autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) triggered by infectious mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus).
  • In hemolytic anemia, haptoglobin binds free hemoglobin released from destroyed red blood cells, leading to decreased serum haptoglobin levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased reticulocyte count: Reticulocyte count would be increased, not decreased, due to compensatory bone marrow response.

 

Option C. Decreased mean corpuscular volume: Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is typically normal or slightly increased in hemolytic anemia.

 

Option D. Increased direct to total bilirubin ratio: Direct to total bilirubin ratio is usually decreased because hemolysis increases indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the clinic with 2 months of worsening fatigue and persistent lower back pain that is aggravated by movement. Physical examination shows pallor and tenderness over the lower spine. Radiographic imaging reveals lytic bone lesions. Laboratory findings include:

 

Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL

Serum creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL

Serum calcium: 11.0 mg/dL

 

Urine dipstick is negative for protein, but 24-hour urine protein quantification shows elevated protein levels. Urine electrophoresis is most likely to detect which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lambda light chains

 

  • The patient's presentation of fatigue, anemia, back pain with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal dysfunction is classic for multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy producing excess monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains (either kappa or lambda).
  • These free light chains are filtered by the kidney and appear in the urine as Bence Jones proteins.
  • Urine electrophoresis in multiple myeloma typically detects excess free light chains (kappa or lambda) rather than intact immunoglobulins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma heavy chains: Gamma heavy chains are seen in heavy chain diseases, which are rare.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin G and C. Immunoglobulin M: Immunoglobulin G or M refers to intact immunoglobulins, which typically show up in serum electrophoresis rather than urine.

questions.text:
Which of the following are reduced in Iron Deficiency Anemia?

 

  1. Ferritin
  2. TIBC
  3. Transferrin saturation
  4. RDW
  5. Hepcidin 
  6. Soluble transferrin receptor
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 5

 

In Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA), the following changes are typically observed:

 

  1. Ferritin: Reduced — Ferritin is the storage form of iron, and its levels decrease in IDA because the body's iron stores are depleted.
  2. TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity): Increased — TIBC increases as the body produces more transferrin to maximize iron binding and transport when iron is low.
  3. Transferrin Saturation: Reduced — Since there is less iron to bind, the percentage of transferrin saturated with iron decreases.
  4. RDW (Red Cell Distribution Width): Increased — RDW is increased due to variation in red blood cell size caused by iron deficiency.
  5. Hepcidin: Reduced — Hepcidin, which inhibits iron absorption, is decreased in IDA to promote more iron absorption from the gut.
  6. Soluble Transferrin Receptor: Increased — Elevated in IDA because cells upregulate transferrin receptors to capture more iron.

 

Thus, the parameters that are reduced in Iron Deficiency Anemia are:

 

  • Ferritin (1)
  • Transferrin Saturation (3)
  • Hepcidin (5)

choices.text: RBC mass increased, O2 saturation increased, EPO decreased
RBC mass increased, O2 saturation normal, EPO decreased
RBC mass increased, O2 saturation increased, EPO normal
RBC mass normal , O2 saturation normal, EPO increased

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with unbearable itching while taking a shower which has been present for many months. Physical examination shows the presence of facial plethora. Laboratory examination shows a hemoglobin of 20 g/dL. What would be the best match for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RBC mass increased, O2 saturation normal, EPO decreased

 

The clinical presentation of this 65-year-old male with facial plethora, a very high hemoglobin (20 g/dL), and itching (especially during showers) is suggestive of polycythemia vera (PV), a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased red blood cell mass.

 

Key features supporting this diagnosis:

 

  • Facial plethora is a classic sign of PV.
  • Pruritus, particularly after a hot shower, is a characteristic symptom of PV.
  • Elevated hemoglobin reflects increased RBC mass.
  • In PV, erythropoietin (EPO) levels are typically decreased because the increased RBC production is independent of EPO stimulation.
  • Oxygen saturation is usually normal, as PV is not caused by hypoxia.

 

Therefore, the best match is:

 

B) RBC mass increased, O2 saturation normal, EPO decreased

 

This matches the provided answer and fits the clinical and laboratory findings perfectly.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with poor prognosis in a patient with multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) t(11;14) 

 

t(11;14) translocation, in contrast, is generally considered to be associated with a better or standard prognosis, not poor prognosis.

 

In multiple myeloma, certain cytogenetic abnormalities and laboratory markers are associated with prognosis:

 

  • t(4;14) translocation is associated with poor prognosis.
  • High serum beta-2 microglobulin reflects tumor burden and renal function, and is linked with poor prognosis.
  • Low serum albumin is a marker of poor nutritional and general health status and correlates with poor prognosis.

questions.text: All of the following anticoagulants inhibit both Factor Xa and Factor IIa, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fondaparinux

 

This drug inhibit both Factor Xa & Factor IIa

 

Fondaparinux selectively inhibits only Factor Xa and does not inhibit Factor IIa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unfractionated heparin: Unfractionated heparin inhibits both Factor Xa and Factor IIa (thrombin).

 

Option B. LMWH: Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) inhibits both Factor Xa and Factor IIa, although it has a stronger effect on Factor Xa.

questions.text: Lipid profile of a patient who suffered from acute coronary syndrome is given. He has LDL 127 g/dl, HDL 32 mg/dl, and Triglycerides are 278 mg/dl. What drug can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atorvastatin 80 mg 

 

Atorvastatin 80 mg should be started in this patient.

 

High-Intensity Statin Therapy is recommended for ACS patients irrespective of baseline LDL, to quickly lower LDL and reduce future cardiovascular risk.

 

High intensity statins: Atorvastatin 40-80mg daily, Rosuvastatin 20-40mg daily

 

This patient has had acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and LDL 127 mg/dl.

Target LDL guidelines in ACS patients: 

 

  • AHA guidelines: reduce LDL by > 50 percent or < 70 mg/dl.
  • European guidelines: reduce LDL < 55 mg/dl

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fenofibrates 160 mg: 

 

  • Fibrates reduces triglyceride levels
  • Indicated if TGs > 350 mg/dl.
  • High intensity statins such as Atorvastatin 40-80 mg, rosuvastatin 20-40 mg are preferred, not moderate intensity Atorvastatin 10-20 mg/dl, risuvastatin 5-10 mg/dl.

 

Option B. Rosuvastatin + Fenofibrate: Not indicated as first line for ACS. 

 

Option C. Rosuvastatin 10 mg: For patients with ACS, High intensity statins such as Atorvastatin 40-80 mg, rosuvastatin 20-40 mg are preferred, not moderate intensity Atorvastatin 10-20 mg/dl, risuvastatin 5-10 mg/dl.

 

Dosage of statins:

 

 

High intensity statins indications:

 

  • Clinical ASCVD/Acute Coronary Syndrome
  • Prophylaxis for patients with history of Angina/myocardial infarction/stroke
  • LDL > 190 mg/dl
  • Hypertriglyceridemia with ASCVD risk

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency with burning chest pain. Examine the ECG shown below. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal Sinus rhythum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sinus tachycardia: Regular rhythm with a heart rate above 100 bpm.

 

Option B. Irregular rhythm: Heartbeats occur at irregular intervals, often seen in arrhythmias like atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Sinus bradycardia: Regular rhythm with a heart rate below 60 bpm.

choices.text: More than 20% blasts in blood or bone marrow
Minimal or absent dysplasia in myeloid lineages

questions.text: Which of the following is not compatible with a diagnosis of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More than 20% blasts in blood or bone marrow

 

  • Blasts in blood or bone marrow are usually less than 20%; more than 20% blasts (A) suggest transformation to acute leukemia, which is not compatible with a diagnosis of CMML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absence of Philadelphia chromosome: Absence of the Philadelphia chromosome to distinguish it from chronic myeloid leukemia.

 

Option C. Peripheral blood monocytosis >1×10⁹/L: Peripheral blood monocytosis >1×10⁹/L  as a hallmark feature.

 

Option D. Minimal or absent dysplasia in myeloid lineages: Dysplasia in one or more myeloid lineages is usually present; minimal or absent dysplasia is not typical in CMML.

questions.text:
Which of the following methods can be used to calculate cardiac output?


1. Thermodilution
2. ECHO
3. Fick’s principle
4. Plethysmography
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Methods to calculate cardiac output include:

 

1. Thermodilution: An invasive technique using a catheter to measure temperature changes.

2. Echocardiography (ECHO): A non-invasive imaging method estimating cardiac output.

3. Fick’s principle: Based on oxygen consumption and arterial-venous oxygen difference.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

4. Plethysmography: Generally used to measure changes in volume or blood flow in limbs, not cardiac output directly. Plethysmography is not typically used to calculate cardiac output. It is used for calculation of residual capacity of lung.

choices.text: 6 mg IV bolus over 2–3 minutes followed by saline flush
6 mg IV bolus over 2–3 seconds followed by a rapid flush with 20 mL normal saline
6 mg slow IV infusion over 20–30 minutes
6 mg slow infusion over 20 minutes, followed by 12 mg over 40 minutes

questions.text: How should adenosine be administered to a patient with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) for pharmacological cardioversion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 mg IV bolus over 2–3 seconds followed by a rapid flush with 20 mL normal saline

 

This rapid administration followed by a quick saline flush ensures adenosine reaches the heart quickly to effectively terminate the arrhythmia.

 

Summary of adenosine administration via peripheral vs central IV routes for SVT:

 

  • Peripheral IV Route (commonly antecubital vein): Adenosine is given as a rapid IV bolus (1-3 seconds), immediately followed by a rapid saline flush (20 mL). This route is most commonly used due to ease and safety. However, the initial effective dose is sometimes less, and multiple doses might be needed to terminate SVT because some drug may be metabolized before reaching the heart.
  • Central IV Route (e.g., jugular or subclavian vein): Administration directly into a central vein delivers adenosine closer to the heart, resulting in quicker and often more effective termination of SVT with a potentially lower dose. Studies show central administration may require lower total doses and has a faster effect, but it is more invasive.

 

In essence, peripheral IV is standard and safe but may require higher doses due to dilution and metabolism. Central IV administration is more dose-efficient and faster but less commonly used due to invasiveness.

 

This difference mainly stems from the proximity of the administration site to the heart and adenosine’s very short half-life.

questions.text: A patient with chest pain and palpitations has BP 130/90 mmHg and pulse 101/min. Echocardiography shows right atrial collapse during diastole. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pericardiocentesis

 

Right atrial collapse during diastole on echocardiography is a classic sign of cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening emergency where pericardial fluid accumulation impairs heart filling.

 

In a patient with chest pain, palpitations, and signs of tamponade (right atrial collapse), the most appropriate management is: Pericardiocentesis

 

This procedure removes the pericardial fluid to relieve pressure on the heart. NSAIDs and steroids are used for pericarditis but are not appropriate for tamponade. Chest tube or thoracotomy is for pneumothorax or hemothorax, not tamponade.

choices.text: Autoantibodies are formed against factor VIII
Presents in childhood or early adulthood

questions.text: Which of the following is false about acquired hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presents in childhood or early adulthood

 

It typically presents in older adults, not in childhood or early adulthood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoantibodies are formed against factor VIII: True. Autoantibodies (inhibitors) form against factor VIII, causing bleeding.

 

Option B. Associated with lymphoproliferative malignancies: True. It can be associated with lymphoproliferative malignancies, autoimmune diseases, pregnancy, or idiopathic causes.

 

Option D. Bethesda assay confirms the diagnosis: True. Bethesda assay is used to confirm the presence and quantify factor VIII inhibition.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with a long history of alcohol use disorder presents to the primary care physician with shortness of breath and increasing fatigue over the past year. The patient has also experienced decreased exercise tolerance and mild lower extremity swelling. He denies chest pain, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or changes in his bowel movements. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure of 118/78 mmHg, heart rate of 80 beats/min, and respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min. Physical exam reveals diffuse bibasilar crackles, abdominal distension, and 2+ pitting lower extremity edema. Doppler echocardiography shows reduced left and right ventricular wall motion with an ejection fraction of 33%. The patient is counseled on the importance of reducing his alcohol consumption. he physician also explains that he will start the patient on a new medication to reduce harmful cardiac remodeling due to the actions of an endogenous vasoconstricting peptide hormone. The next day, the patient calls complaining of lightheadedness and dizziness. His last at-home blood pressure reading was 95/60 mmHg. Which of the following medications was this patient most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enalapril


The side effects experienced by this patient are consistent with the use of an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi) such as enalapril. ACEis are medications indicated in the treatment of hypertension heart failure, and renal disease. They work by inhibiting the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), which prevents downstream production of angiotensin II, an endogenous peptide hormone. Because angiotensin plays a vital role in pathologic cardiac remodelling, ACE inhibitors can help inhibit this process.


In addition to the cardiac effects described above, ACEis block the vasoconstrictive effect of angiotensin II and decrease aldosterone production. The cumulative effect decreased blood pressure. Of note, there is a risk of first-dose hypotension with these medications, especially in patients with pre-existing hypovolemia and high renin levels. This complication may be mitigated by starting with low doses of ACEis and avoiding the concomitant administration of ACEi and Atorvastatin.

 

MOA OF ACEi & ARBs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atorvastatin: Lipid-lowering, no effect on remodeling or vasoconstriction.

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Aldosterone antagonist; can reduce remodeling but less likely the first medication started.

 

Option C. Budesonide: Corticosteroid, unrelated.

choices.text: Left coronary and right marginal arteries
Left anterior descending and right coronary arteries
Right coronary and left circumflex arteries

questions.text: A 66-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension and a 10 pack-year cigarette smoking history comes to the cardiologist with intermittent chest pain. He previously had chest pain only when walking his dog, which subsided with rest; however, he now has pain while watching TV or reading the newspaper. The patient denies a correlation between his symptoms and eating. His family history includes coronary artery disease in his father at age 55. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg, pulse is 88 min, and respirations are 16/min. The patient is in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary auscultation reveals a regular S1 and S2 with no rubs, murmurs, or gallops and clear breath sounds throughout. Extremities are warm and well-perfused. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without ST-segment elevations, Q waves, or T wave inversions. Troponin levels are < 0.01 ng/mL. The patient undergoes evaluation by coronary angiography, revealing a partial occlusion of the posterior descending artery and codominant circulation. Which of the following vessels most likely supply the posterior descending artery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right coronary and left circumflex arteries


Coronary Arteries of the Heart: 

 

Distribution: Left-D = 8%
 

Codominant = 7%
 

Right =85%

questions.text: A previously healthy 37-year-old female, gravida 0 para 0, presents to the gynecology office with cyclic pelvic pain and bloating. She has been experiencing these symptoms for the past three years but has been unable to seek care due to insurance issues. She describes her menstrual cycles as "heavy" and states they occur every 28 days and last seven to ten days. She denies significant pain or cramping associated with her periods Vital signs and physical exam are unremarkable. The physician orders a pelvic ultrasound, which shows the presence of multiple uterine leiomyomas, with the largest measuring 10 cm by 8 cm. A complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL. Peripheral blood smear shows the presence of several large cells with bluish-tinted cytoplasm. Dark blue dots and curved linear structures are observed in the cytoplasm with the Romanowsky stain. Which of the following best describes these inclusions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ribosomal genetic material

 

The blue dots and linear filaments represent ribosomal RNA in reticulocytes or immature erythrocytes, consistent with the patient's anemia and increased reticulocyte production. To cope up with anemic status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Denatured hemoglobin: This would appear as Heinz bodies, which require supravital staining, not Romanowsky, and are not described as blue dots or linear structures.

 

Option B. Iron deposits: Appear as hemosiderin, typically brownish pigments, and identified with Prussian blue stain, not Romanowsky. These are typically seen in Hemosiderosis, a genetic disease caused by mutation of HFE

 

Option C. Nuclear remnants: Howell-Jolly bodies, which are nuclear remnants, appear as single, round basophilic inclusions, not multiple dots or lines., seen in Post splenectomy states due to sickle cell anemia, Hereditary Spherocytosis, etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reticulocytes can be identified on peripheral blood smear as cells with bluish-gray inclusions with Romanowsky-Giemsa stain from residual ribonucleic acid (RNA) in the cytoplasm.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female with a past medical history of hypothyroidism, HlV, and psoriasis presents to the emergency department with a one-month history of weight loss and night sweats. She unintentionally lost 13 Iibs (5.9 kg) over the previous month. The patient complains of significant fatigue, requiring naps throughout the day. Her current medications include levothyroxine, lamivudine, efavirenz, maraviroc, and topical hydrocortisone cream. She denies tobacco and alcohol use but admits to using intravenous heroin regularly over the past eight years. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 122/82 mmHg, heart rate of 68 beats/ min, respiratory rate of 17 breaths/min, and temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical exam reveals multiple enlarged, nontender cervical lymph nodes. A dermatologic exam reveals multiple erythematous lesions and needle track marks on both arms. Her abdomen is nontender and nondistended. A lymph node biopsy is scheduled for the following week. Which of the following will most likely be observed on this biopsy if a t(8;14) translocation is detected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tingible body macrophages

 

The patient's presentation (weight loss, night sweats, fatigue, enlarged cervical lymph nodes, IV drug use) raises suspicion for lymphoma.

 

The t(8;14) translocation is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma. Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma frequently associated with this translocation involving the c-MYC oncogene on chromosome 8 and the immunoglobulin heavy chain locus on chromosome 14.

 

Histologically, Burkitt lymphoma often shows a "starry sky" appearance due to numerous tingible body macrophages that have ingested apoptotic tumor cells.

 

Burkitt's lymphoma is a highly aggressive form of lymphoma. It can be divided into endemic, sporadic, and immunodeficiency-related variants. The endemic form primarily affects children, classically presenting as maxillary or mandibular expansile tumors that can spread to adjacent cervical lymph nodes. The sporadic variant also primarily affects children but frequently involves the abdominal region.

choices.text: Agonist causing an increase in cGMP
Gi antagonist causing an increase in cAMP
Gq agonist causing an increase in IP3
Gs agonist causing activation of adenylate cyclase

questions.text: A 64-year-old female with a past medical history of a right below-the-knee amputation with a transtibial prosthesis presents to the cardiologist for a cardiac stress test. She reports exertional chest pain and shortness of breath when walking to pick up her mail each afternoon. The pain is never present at rest. Due to her history of amputation and prosthesis, she is not a candidate for exercise stress testing. Therefore, the physician administers a medication that will induce a similar response. Following administration, the patient reports a crushing chest pain similar to her reported symptoms. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gs agonist causing activation of adenylate cyclase

 

This describes beta-adrenergic receptor stimulation by dobutamine, which increases cAMP via Gs and adenylate cyclase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agonist causing an increase in cGMP: Likely refers to beta-adrenergic agonists (like dobutamine), which stimulate Gs protein, activating adenylate cyclase, increasing cAMP, and increasing heart rate and contractility.

 

Option B. Gi antagonist causing increase in cAMP: Gi inhibits adenylate cyclase; antagonizing Gi leads to increased cAMP, but this is indirect and less common as a direct drug mechanism.

 

Option C. Gq agonist causing increase in IP3: Gq protein activation leads to phospholipase C activation and IP3 increase; not typical for pharmacologic stress agents.

questions.text: A 10-year-old female who recently moved to the area presents to the cardiologist to establish care. The patient's father reports his daughter has always been "on the shorter side" and had a genetic abnormality noted on karyotype analysis during prenatal screening, but he does not recall the details. On physical exam, the patient appears short with a broadened chest. Excess skin folds extend along the lateral aspect of her neck bilaterally, and her toenails appear dysplastic. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) completed at the patient's previous healthcare facility shows a narrowing of the aorta at the isthmus. Which of the following findings will most likely be appreciated on this patient's physical exam?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Brachial-femoral delay

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests this patient has Turner syndrome, a condition characterized by a karyotype abnormality involving the X chromosome and typical features including short stature, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, bilateral webbed neck (excess skin folds along the neck), dysplastic nails, and congenital heart defects. A common congenital heart defect in Turner syndrome is coarctation of the aorta, especially near the isthmus (segment just distal to the left subclavian artery).

 

On physical exam, coarctation of the aorta typically presents with:

 

  • Weak or delayed femoral pulses compared to brachial pulses
  • A significant difference in blood pressure between the arms and lower extremities
  • A brachial-femoral pulse delay or discrepancy
